text:
The **economy of Armenia** grew by 5.9% in 2024, according to estimates by the
International Monetary Fund, with total output amounting to $25.5 billion. GDP
contracted sharply in 2020 by 7.1%, mainly due to the COVID-19 recession and
the Second Nagorno-Karabakh War with Azerbaijan. In contrast it grew by 7.6%
in 2019, 5.8% in 2021, 12.6% in 2022 and 8.3% in 2023. Between 2012 and 2018
GDP grew 40.7%, and key banking indicators like assets and credit exposures
almost doubled.

While part of the Soviet Union, the economy of Armenia was based largely on
manufacturing industry—chemicals, electronic products, machinery, processed
food, synthetic rubber and textiles; it was highly dependent on outside
resources. Armenian mines produce copper, zinc, gold and lead. The vast
majority of energy is produced with imported fuel from Russia, including gas
and nuclear fuel for Armenia's Metsamor nuclear power plant. The main domestic
energy source is hydroelectric.[_dubious – discuss_] Small amounts of coal,
gas, and petroleum have not yet been developed.

The severe trade imbalance has been somewhat offset by international aid and
remittances from Armenians abroad, and foreign direct investment. Armenia is a
member of the Eurasian Economic Union and ties with Russia remain close,
especially in the energy sector.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Armenia grew by 5.9% in 2024, according to estimates by the International Monetary Fund, with the total output reaching $25.5 billion.
• In 2020, Armenia's GDP contracted sharply by 7.1%, primarily due to the COVID-19 recession and the Second Nagorno-Karabakh War with Azerbaijan.
• The country's GDP growth rates in recent years include 7.6% in 2019, 5.8% in 2021, 12.6% in 2022, and 8.3% in 2023.
• Between 2012 and 2018, Armenia's GDP increased by 40.7%, with significant growth in key banking indicators such as assets and credit exposures, which nearly doubled during this period.

• Historically, while part of the Soviet Union, Armenia's economy was primarily based on manufacturing industries, including chemicals, electronic products, machinery, processed food, synthetic rubber, and textiles, and was highly dependent on external resources.
• Armenian mines produce copper, zinc, gold, and lead, contributing to the country's mineral resource sector.
• The majority of Armenia's energy is generated using imported fuel from Russia, including natural gas and nuclear fuel for the Metsamor nuclear power plant.
• The main domestic energy source in Armenia is hydroelectric power, although small amounts of coal, gas, and petroleum are present but underdeveloped.
• Armenia faces a severe trade imbalance, which has been partially mitigated by international aid, remittances from Armenians abroad, and foreign direct investment.
• Armenia is a member of the Eurasian Economic Union, maintaining close ties with Russia, especially in the energy sector.

text:
Under the old Soviet central planning system, Armenia had developed a modern
industrial sector, supplying machine tools, textiles, and other manufactured
goods to sister republics in exchange for raw materials and energy. Since the
implosion of the USSR in December 1991, Armenia has switched to small-scale
agriculture away from the large agroindustrial complexes of the Soviet era.
The agricultural sector has long-term needs for more investment and updated
technology. Armenia began borrowing soon after declaring independence. In
2000, Armenian governmental debt reached its greatest level relative to GDP
(49.3 percent of GDP).

Armenia is a food importer, and its mineral deposits (gold and bauxite) are
small. The ongoing conflict with Azerbaijan over the ethnic Armenian-dominated
region of Nagorno-Karabakh and the breakup of the centrally directed economic
system of the former Soviet Union contributed to a severe economic decline in
the early 1990s. Political instability and the threat of war placed a
significant strain on economic development. Despite robust growth in recent
years, the problem of geopolitical uncertainty resurfaced during the 2020 war,
contributing to a 7.1% drop in GDP. Armenia's public debt rose to 67.4% in
2020, but fell below 50% again in 2022.
openai_summarised_points: • Under the Soviet central planning system, Armenia developed a modern industrial sector that supplied machine tools, textiles, and other manufactured goods to sister republics in exchange for raw materials and energy.
• Following the collapse of the USSR in December 1991, Armenia shifted from large agroindustrial complexes to small-scale agriculture.
• The agricultural sector in Armenia has long-term needs for increased investment and modernization through updated technology.
• Armenia began borrowing funds shortly after declaring independence in 1991.
• In 2000, Armenia's governmental debt reached its highest level relative to GDP at 49.3 percent.
• Armenia is primarily a food importer.
• The country's mineral deposits, including gold and bauxite, are relatively small.

• The ongoing conflict with Azerbaijan over the Nagorno-Karabakh region, which is predominantly inhabited by ethnic Armenians, and the disintegration of the Soviet Union’s centrally planned economy contributed to a severe economic decline in the early 1990s.
• Political instability and the threat of war significantly hindered economic development during this period.
• Despite recent robust growth, geopolitical uncertainty resurfaced during the 2020 war, leading to a 7.1 percent decrease in Armenia’s GDP.
• Armenia’s public debt increased to 67.4 percent of GDP in 2020.
• By 2022, Armenia’s public debt had decreased to below 50 percent of GDP.

text:
In the 2020 report of Index of Economic Freedom by The Heritage Foundation,
Armenia is classified as "mostly free" and ranks 34th, improving by 13
positions and ahead of all other Eurasian Economic Union countries and several
EU countries including Cyprus, Bulgaria, Romania, Poland, Belgium, Spain,
France, Portugal and Italy.

In the 2019 report (data for 2017) of Economic Freedom of the World published
by Fraser Institute Armenia ranks 27th (classified most free) out of 162
economies.

In the 2019 report of Global Competitiveness Index Armenia ranks 69th out of
141 economies.

In the 2020 report (data for 2019) of Doing Business Index Armenia ranks 47th
with 10th rank on "starting business" sub-index.

In the 2019 report (data for 2018) of Human Development Index by UNDP Armenia
ranked 81st and is classified into "high human development" group.

In the 2021 report (data for 2020) of Corruption Perceptions Index by
Transparency International Armenia ranked 49 of 179 countries.
openai_summarised_points: • In the 2020 report of the Index of Economic Freedom published by The Heritage Foundation, Armenia is classified as "mostly free" and is ranked 34th globally, representing an improvement of 13 positions from previous rankings.
• Armenia's 2020 Index of Economic Freedom ranking places it ahead of all other countries within the Eurasian Economic Union.
• Armenia also outperforms several European Union member states, including Cyprus, Bulgaria, Romania, Poland, Belgium, Spain, France, Portugal, and Italy, according to the 2020 report.
• The 2019 report of the Economic Freedom of the World, published by the Fraser Institute, based on data from 2017, ranks Armenia 27th out of 162 economies, categorizing it as "most free."
• In the 2019 Global Competitiveness Index report, Armenia is ranked 69th out of 141 economies.
• The 2020 Doing Business Index (based on 2019 data) ranks Armenia 47th globally, with a particularly high score of 10th place on the "starting a business" sub-index.
• According to the 2019 Human Development Index report by UNDP, based on 2018 data, Armenia was ranked 81st and classified within the "high human development" group.
• The 2021 Corruption Perceptions Index by Transparency International, based on 2020 data, ranks Armenia 49th out of 179 countries.

section_name: History of the modern Armenian economy
text:
At the beginning of the 20th century, the territory of present-day Armenia was
an agricultural region with some copper mining and cognac production. From
1914 through 1921, Caucasian Armenia suffered from the genocide of about 1.5
million Armenian inhabitants in their own homeland which caused total property
and financial collapse when all of their assets and belongings were forcibly
taken away by the Turks, the consequences of which after 105 years to this day
remain incalculable, revolution, the influx of refugees from Turkish Armenia,
disease, hunger and economic misery. About 200,000 people died in 1919 alone.
At that point, only American relief efforts saved Armenia from total collapse.
Thus, Armenians went from being one of the wealthiest ethnic groups in the
region to suffering from poverty and famine.[_citation needed_] Armenians were
the second richest ethnic group in Anatolia after the Greeks, and they were
heavily involved in very high productive sectors such as banking,
architecture, and trade. However, after the mass killings of Armenian
intellectuals in April 1915 and the genocide targeted towards the whole
Armenian population left the people and the country in ruins. The genocide was
responsible for the loss of many high-quality skills that the Armenians
possessed.

100 million rubles banknote

The first Soviet Armenian government regulated economic activity stringently,
nationalizing all economic enterprises, requisitioning grain from peasants,
and suppressing most private market activity. This first experiment of state
control ended with the advent of Soviet leader Vladimir Lenin's New Economic
Policy (NEP) of 1921–1927. This policy continued state control of the large
enterprises and banks, but peasants could market much of their grain, and
small businesses could function. In Armenia, the NEP years brought partial
recovery from the economic disaster of the post-World War I period. By 1926
agricultural production in Armenia had reached nearly three-quarters of its
prewar level.

By the end of the 1920s, Stalin's regime had revoked the NEP and re-
established the centralised state monopoly on all economic activity. Once this
occurred, the main goal of the Soviet economic policy in Armenia was to turn a
predominantly agrarian and rural republic into an industrial and urban one.
Among other restrictions, peasants now were forced to sell nearly all of their
output to state procurement agencies rather than at the open market. From the
1930s through the 1960s, an industrial infrastructure has been constructed.
Besides hydroelectric plants and canals, roads were built and gas pipelines
were laid to bring fuel and food from Azerbaijan and Russia.

The state socialist command economy, in which market forces were suppressed
and all orders for production and distribution came from the state
authorities, survived in all its essential features until the fall of the
Soviet regime in 1991. In the early stages of the communist economic
revolution, Armenia underwent a fundamental transformation into a
"proletarian" society. Between 1929 and 1939, the percentage of Armenia's work
force categorised as industrial workers grew from 13% to 31%. By 1935 industry
supplied 62% of Armenia's economic production. Highly integrated and sheltered
within artificial barter economy of the Soviet system from the 1930s until the
end of the communist era, the Armenian economy showed few signs of self-
sufficiency at any time during that period. In 1988, Armenia produced only
0.9% of the net material product of the Soviet Union (1.2% of industry, 0.7%
of agriculture). The republic retained 1.4% of total state budget revenue,
delivered 63.7% of its NMP to other republics, and exported only 1.4% of what
it produced to markets outside the Soviet Union.

Agriculture accounted for only 20% of net material product and 10% of
employment before the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991.

Armenia's industry was especially dependent on the Soviet military-industrial
complex. About 40% of all enterprises in the republic were devoted to defense,
and some factories lost 60% to 80% of their business in the last years of the
Soviet Union, when massive cuts were made in the national defense
expenditures. As the republic's economy faced the prospects of competing in
world markets in the mid-1990s, the great liabilities of Armenia's industry
were its outdated equipment and infrastructure and the pollution emitted by
many of the country's heavy industrial plants.

The economic downturn that began in 1989 worsened dramatically in 1992.
According to statistics, the GDP declined by 37.5 percent in 1991 compared to
1990, and all sectors contributing to the GDP decreased in production. The
collapse of industry in favor of agriculture, whose products were mostly
imported throughout the Soviet period, changed the structure of sectoral
contributions to GDP.

In 1991, Armenia's last year as a Soviet republic, national income fell 12%
from the previous year, while per capita gross national product was 4,920
rubles, only 68% of the Soviet average. In large part due to the earthquake of
1988, the Azerbaijani blockade that began in 1989 and the collapse of the
international trading system of the Soviet Union, the Armenian economy of the
early 1990s remained far below its 1980 production levels. In the first years
of independence (1992–93), inflation was extremely high, productivity and
national income dropped dramatically, and the national budget ran large
deficits.

A period of chronic shortages, was the first stage of price deregulation,
which allowed goods to stay in Armenia as opposed to being exported for better
prices; the inflation rates were 10 percent in 1990, 100 percent in 1991, and
642.5 percent during the first four months of 1992, compared with the first
four months of 1991. Thus, there were two opposing dynamics: price increases
in response to shortages and falling incomes due to the recession and
unemployment.
openai_summarised_points: • At the beginning of the 20th century, present-day Armenia was primarily an agricultural region with some copper mining and cognac production.

• Between 1914 and 1921, Caucasian Armenia experienced a genocide that resulted in approximately 1.5 million Armenian deaths and caused a total economic collapse due to the confiscation of assets by the Turks.
• The genocide's consequences, including revolution, refugee influx, disease, hunger, and economic misery, remain incalculable after 105 years; about 200,000 Armenians died in 1919 alone.
• American relief efforts in 1919 played a crucial role in preventing Armenia's total collapse during this period.
• Prior to the genocide, Armenians were the second wealthiest ethnic group in Anatolia after the Greeks, heavily involved in banking, architecture, and trade.
• The genocide in April 1915 and the targeting of Armenian intellectuals devastated the population and economy, leading to significant loss of skilled human capital.

• The first Soviet Armenian government implemented strict economic regulation, including nationalization of enterprises, requisitioning grain from peasants, and suppression of private market activity.

• This initial Soviet economic control ended with Vladimir Lenin's New Economic Policy (NEP) of 1921–1927, which maintained state control over large enterprises and banks but allowed peasants to sell surplus grain and small businesses to operate.
• During the NEP years, Armenia experienced partial economic recovery; by 1926, agricultural production reached nearly 75% of prewar levels.
• By the late 1920s, Stalin's regime revoked the NEP, re-establishing centralized state monopoly over all economic activity in Armenia.

• Under Stalin, the primary goal was transforming Armenia from an agrarian society into an industrial and urban one, with peasants now required to sell nearly all output to state procurement agencies.
• From the 1930s to the 1960s, Armenia developed an industrial infrastructure including hydroelectric plants, canals, roads, and gas pipelines connecting to Azerbaijan and Russia.
• The Soviet socialist command economy persisted until the fall of the Soviet Union in 1991, characterized by suppressed market forces and centralized planning.
• Between 1929 and 1939, Armenia's industrial workforce increased from 13% to 31%, and by 1935, industry contributed 62% of the republic’s economic output.

• Throughout the Soviet era, Armenia's economy remained highly integrated within the Soviet barter system, showing little signs of self-sufficiency; in 1988, Armenia produced only 0.9% of the Soviet Union’s net material product, with 1.2% from industry and 0.7% from agriculture.
• Armenia's share of total Soviet state budget revenue was 1.4%, and it exported only 1.4% of its production outside the USSR.
• Agriculture constituted approximately 20% of Armenia’s net material product and 10% of employment before the 1991 Soviet breakup.

• Armenia's industry was heavily dependent on the Soviet military-industrial complex, with about 40% of enterprises dedicated to defense; many factories lost 60–80% of their business in the late Soviet period due to defense budget cuts.

• In the mid-1990s, Armenia faced significant industrial liabilities, including outdated equipment, infrastructure deficiencies, and pollution from heavy industrial plants, hindering competitiveness in global markets.
• The economic downturn intensified in 1992, with GDP declining by 37.5% in 1991 compared to 1990, and all sectors contributing to GDP experiencing decreased production.
• The collapse of industry in favor of import-dependent agriculture altered Armenia’s sectoral contribution to GDP during this period.
• In 1991, Armenia's last Soviet year, national income decreased by 12% from the previous year, with per capita gross national product at 4,920 rubles—only 68% of the Soviet average.
• The 1988 earthquake, the Azerbaijani blockade starting in 1989, and the collapse of the Soviet international trade system caused Armenia’s early 1990s economy to remain well below 1980 levels.
• During 1992–93, Armenia experienced extremely high inflation, significant drops in productivity and national income, and large deficits in the national budget.

• Early post-independence shortages led to price deregulation, with inflation rates rising from 10% in 1990 to 100% in 1991, and reaching 642.5% in the first four months of 1992, compared to the same period in 1991.
• The economic crisis was characterized by conflicting dynamics: rising prices due to shortages and falling incomes due to recession and unemployment.

text:
Armenia introduced elements of the free market and privatisation into their
economic system in the late 1980s, when Mikhail Gorbachev began advocating
economic reform. To supply the country's basic needs, the first decision was
land reform and the privatization of land. This allowed for the emergence of
small-parcel agriculture supplying markets and supporting self-sustenance
during the period of shortages. Cooperatives were set up in the service
sector, particularly in restaurants, although substantial resistance came from
the Communist Party of Armenia (CPA) and other groups that had enjoyed
privileged position in the old economy. In the late 1980s, much of Armenia's
economy already was opening either semi-officially or illegally, with
widespread corruption and bribery. The so-called mafia, made up of
interconnected groups of powerful officials and their relatives and friends,
sabotaged the efforts of reformers to create a lawful market system. When the
December 1988 earthquake brought millions of dollars of foreign aid to the
devastated regions of Armenia, much of the money went to corrupt and criminal
elements.

Beginning in 1991, the democratically elected government pushed vigorously for
privatisation and market relations, although its efforts were frustrated by
the old ways of doing business in Armenia, the Azerbaijani blockade, and the
costs of the First Nagorno-Karabakh War. In 1992, the Law on the Programme of
Privatisation and Decentralisation of Incompletely Constructed Facilities
established a state privatisation committee, with members from all political
parties. In the middle of 1993, the committee announced a two-year
privatisation programme, whose first stage would be privatisation of 30% of
state enterprises, mostly services and light industries. The remaining 70%,
including many bankrupt, nonfunctional enterprises, were to be privatised in a
later stage with a minimum of government restriction, to encourage private
initiative. For all enterprises, the workers would receive 20% of their firm's
property free of charge; 30% would be distributed to all citizens by means of
vouchers; and the remaining 50% was to be distributed by the government, with
preference given to members of the labour organisations. A major problem of
this system, however, was the lack of supporting legislation covering foreign
investment protection, bankruptcy, monopoly policy, and consumer protection.

In the first post-communist years, efforts to interest foreign investors in
joint enterprises were only moderately successful because of the blockade and
the energy shortage. Only in late 1993 was a department of foreign investment
established in the Ministry of Economy, to spread information about Armenia's
investment opportunities and improve the legal infrastructure for investment
activity. A specific goal of this agency was creating a market for scientific
and technical intellectual property.

A few Armenians living abroad made large-scale investments. Besides a toy
factory and construction projects, diaspora Armenians built a cold storage
plant (which in its first years had little produce to store) and established
the American University of Armenia in Yerevan to teach the techniques
necessary to run a market economy.

Armenia was admitted to the International Monetary Fund in May 1992 and to the
World Bank in September. A year later, the government complained that those
organisations were holding back financial assistance and announced its
intention to move toward fuller price liberalisation, and the removal of all
tariffs, quotas, and restrictions of foreign trade. Although privatisation had
slowed because of catastrophic collapse of the economy, Prime Minister Hrant
Bagratyan informed the United States officials in the fall of 1993 that plans
had been made to embark on a renewed privatisation programme by the end of the
year.

Like other former states, Armenia's economy suffers from the legacy of a
centrally planned economy and the breakdown of former Soviet trading patterns.
Soviet investment in and support of Armenian industry has virtually
disappeared, so that few major enterprises are still able to function. In
addition, the effects of the 1988 earthquake, which killed more than 25,000
people and made 500,000 homeless, are still being felt. Although a cease-fire
has held since 1994, the conflict with Azerbaijan over Nagorno-Karabakh has
not been resolved. The consequent blockade along both the Azerbaijani and
Turkish borders has devastated the economy, because of Armenia's dependence on
outside supplies of energy and most raw materials. Land routes through
Azerbaijan and Turkey are closed; routes through Georgia and Iran are adequate
and reliable. In 1992–93, the GDP had fallen nearly 60% from its 1989 level.
The national currency, the dram, suffered hyperinflation for the first few
years after its introduction in 1993.

Armenia has registered strong economic growth since 1995 and inflation has
been negligible for the past several years. New sectors, such as precious
stone processing and jewelry making and communication technology (primarily
Armentel, which is left from the USSR era and is owned by external investors).
This steady economic progress has earned Armenia increasing support from
international institutions. The International Monetary Fund (IMF), World Bank,
EBRD, as well as other international financial institutions (IFIs) and foreign
countries are extending considerable grants and loans. Total loans extended to
Armenia since 1993 exceed $800 million. These loans are targeted at reducing
the budget deficit, stabilizing the local currency; developing private
businesses; energy; the agriculture, food processing, transportation, and
health and education sectors; and ongoing rehabilitation work in the
earthquake zone.

By 1994, however, the Armenian government had launched an ambitious IMF-
sponsored economic liberalization program that resulted in positive growth
rates in 1995–2005. The economic growth of Armenia expressed in GDP per capita
was one of strongest in the CIS. GDP went from $350 to more than $800 on
average between 1995 and 2003. Three principal factors explain this result:
the credibility of the macroeconomic policies of stabilization, the correction
effect following the depression, and the importance of external transfers, in
particular since 2000. Armenia became a member of the World Trade Organization
(WTO) in January 2003. Armenia also has managed to slash inflation, stabilize
its currency, and privatize most small- and medium-sized enterprises.
Armenia's unemployment rate, however, remains high, despite strong economic
growth.

The chronic energy shortages Armenia suffered in the early and mid-1990s have
been offset by the energy supplied by one of its nuclear power plants at
Metsamor. Armenia is now a net energy exporter, although it does not have
sufficient generating capacity to replace the Metsamor nuclear plant, which is
under international pressure to close due to its old design. The European
Union had classified the VVER 440 Model V230 light-water-cooled reactors as
the "oldest and least reliable" category of all the 66 Soviet reactors built
in the former Eastern Bloc. However the IAEA has found that the Metsamor NPP
has adequate safety and can function beyond its design lifespan.

The country's electricity distribution system was privatized in 2002.
openai_summarised_points: • Armenia began introducing elements of the free market and privatization into its economic system in the late 1980s, coinciding with Mikhail Gorbachev's advocacy of economic reform.
• The initial reform measures included land reform and land privatization, enabling small-parcel agriculture to supply markets and support self-sustenance amid shortages.

• Cooperatives were established in the service sector, notably in restaurants, but faced substantial resistance from the Communist Party of Armenia (CPA) and other privileged groups from the old economy.

• By the late 1980s, much of Armenia's economy was already operating semi-officially or illegally, characterized by widespread corruption and bribery, with a mafia composed of interconnected groups of officials, relatives, and friends sabotaging reform efforts.

• During the December 1988 earthquake, which caused extensive destruction and displaced over 25,000 people, foreign aid totaling millions of dollars was largely diverted to corrupt and criminal elements.

• Starting in 1991, Armenia’s democratically elected government actively promoted privatization and market reforms, but faced obstacles such as entrenched old business practices, the Azerbaijani blockade, and the costs associated with the First Nagorno-Karabakh War.

• In 1992, the Law on the Programme of Privatisation and Decentralisation of Incompletely Constructed Facilities established a state privatization committee with representatives from all political parties.

• In mid-1993, the committee announced a two-year privatization program targeting 30% of state enterprises—mainly services and light industries—in the first stage, with the remaining 70% to be privatized later with minimal government restrictions to foster private initiative.

• The privatization scheme allocated 20% of each enterprise’s property to workers free of charge, 30% to citizens via vouchers, and 50% to the government with a preference for labor organization members.
• A significant challenge of the privatization system was the absence of supporting legislation on foreign investment protection, bankruptcy, monopoly policy, and consumer protection.

• Early efforts to attract foreign investment through joint enterprises were only moderately successful due to the Azerbaijani blockade and energy shortages; a department of foreign investment was established in the Ministry of Economy in late 1993 to promote investment opportunities and improve legal infrastructure.
• The department aimed to develop a market for scientific and technical intellectual property.

• Diaspora Armenians made large-scale investments, including a toy factory, construction projects, a cold storage plant (initially with limited produce), and the American University of Armenia in Yerevan to teach market economy techniques.

• Armenia joined the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in May 1992 and the World Bank in September 1992; by 1993, the government criticized these organizations for delaying financial aid and announced plans to liberalize prices and eliminate tariffs, quotas, and trade restrictions.
• Despite economic slowdown due to the collapse, Prime Minister Hrant Bagratyan in fall 1993 announced plans to renew privatization efforts by the end of that year.

• Armenia’s economy inherited the legacy of a centrally planned system and the collapse of Soviet trading patterns, with Soviet industrial support virtually vanished, leaving few major enterprises operational.

• The 1988 earthquake, which resulted in over 25,000 deaths and 500,000 homeless, continued to impact the economy, compounded by unresolved conflict with Azerbaijan over Nagorno-Karabakh and a blockade along Azerbaijani and Turkish borders.
• Land routes through Azerbaijan and Turkey were closed, forcing reliance on routes through Georgia and Iran, which were adequate and reliable.
• Between 1992–93, Armenia’s GDP declined nearly 60% from its 1989 level; the national currency, the dram, experienced hyperinflation in its initial years after introduction in 1993.

• Since 1995, Armenia experienced strong economic growth and negligible inflation, with new sectors emerging such as precious stone processing, jewelry making, and communication technology (notably Armentel, a former USSR asset owned by external investors).

• This steady growth garnered increased support from international institutions, with total loans exceeding $800 million since 1993, aimed at reducing the budget deficit, stabilizing the currency, developing private businesses, and rehabilitating earthquake-affected zones.

• By 1994, Armenia launched an IMF-sponsored economic liberalization program, leading to positive GDP growth from 1995 to 2005, with GDP per capita rising from $350 to over $800 between 1995 and 2003.
• The principal factors behind this growth included credible macroeconomic stabilization policies, economic correction after depression, and increased external transfers, especially post-2000.
• Armenia became a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in January 2003.
• The country successfully reduced inflation, stabilized its currency, and privatized most small- and medium-sized enterprises, although unemployment remained high despite economic growth.

• Early and mid-1990s energy shortages were mitigated by nuclear power from the Metsamor plant; Armenia is now a net energy exporter, but the plant faces international pressure to close due to its outdated design.

• The European Union classified the Metsamor VVER 440 Model V230 reactor as the "oldest and least reliable" among Soviet reactors, but the IAEA has affirmed its safety and capacity to operate beyond its design lifespan.
• The electricity distribution system was privatized in 2002.

text:
GDP growth rates in Armenia and some neighboring countries and some regions in
years 2010–2017

According to official preliminary data GDP grew by 7.6 per cent in 2019,
largest recording growth since 2008, leading to Armenia being described as a
"Caucasian Tiger." Nominal GDP per capita was approximately $4,196 in 2018 and
is expected to reach $8,283 in 2023, surpassing neighbouring Azerbaijan and
Georgia.

With 8.3%, Armenia recorded highest degree of GDP growth among Eurasian
Economic Union countries in 2018 January–June against the same period of 2017.

The economy of Armenia had grown by 7.5% in 2017 and reached a nominal GDP of
$11.5 billion per annum, while per capita figure grew by 10.1% and reached
$3880. With 7.29% Armenia was second best in GDP per capita growth terms in
Europe and Central Asia in 2017.

Armenian GDP PPP grew total of 316% per capita in 2000–2017, marking it the
sixth-highest worldwide.

GDP grew 40.7% between 2012 and 2018, and key banking indicators like assets
and credit exposures almost doubled.

openai_summarised_points: • In 2019, Armenia's GDP grew by 7.6%, marking the largest growth rate since 2008, which led to Armenia being described as a "Caucasian Tiger" due to its rapid economic expansion.
• The nominal GDP per capita in Armenia was approximately $4,196 in 2018 and is projected to reach $8,283 by 2023, surpassing neighboring countries Azerbaijan and Georgia in per capita income.
• Armenia recorded the highest GDP growth among Eurasian Economic Union countries in the first half of 2018 (January–June) with a rate of 8.3%, compared to the same period in 2017.

• From 2000 to 2017, Armenia's GDP based on Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) increased by a total of 316% per capita, ranking as the sixth-highest worldwide in this metric.
• Between 2012 and 2018, Armenia's GDP grew by 40.7%, with key banking indicators such as assets and credit exposures nearly doubling in this period.

• According to IMF data covering 1994–2022, Armenia's GDP in millions of drams experienced consistent growth, with notable increases in GDP growth rates and per capita figures, despite some fluctuations such as a -14.1% GDP decline in 2009 and a -7.5% contraction in 2020.

• Armenia's GDP in 2000 was approximately 1,031,338.3 million drams with a 5.9% growth rate; by 2010, GDP increased to 3,460,202.7 million drams with a 2.2% growth rate, and in 2017, it reached 5,564,493.3 million drams with a 7.5% growth rate.
• The GDP deflator, which measures inflation, varied over the years, with notable increases such as +7.8% in 2010, +4.2% in 2011, and fluctuations including a decrease of -1.2% in 2012.
• In 2009, Armenia's GDP contracted by 14.1%, but subsequent years saw recovery and growth, with 2012 experiencing a 7.2% increase, and 2018 recording a 5.2% growth rate.

text:
The Armenian economy performed poorly in 2020, and contracted by 7.2% after
years of consecutive growth. The two biggest contributing factors were the
COVID-19 recession and the Second Nagorno-Karabakh War. In the first half of
2020, the Armenian economy was negatively impacted by the economic
restrictions that were implemented in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. These
restrictions included a stay-at-home order, an indoor social distancing
requirement, and a mask mandate. These restrictions had a negative impact on
businesses; according to the World Bank, individual consumption dropped by 9%
in the first six months of 2020 due to the stay-at-home order.

The economy was further impacted by the war against Azerbaijan later in the
year.
openai_summarised_points: • The Armenian economy experienced a significant decline in 2020, contracting by 7.2%, marking a reversal after years of consecutive economic growth.
• The two primary factors contributing to this economic downturn were the COVID-19 pandemic-induced recession and the Second Nagorno-Karabakh War.

• In the first half of 2020, the economy was adversely affected by measures implemented to curb the spread of COVID-19, including stay-at-home orders, indoor social distancing requirements, and a mask mandate.

• These COVID-19 restrictions negatively impacted business activities and consumer behavior; specifically, the World Bank reported that individual consumption decreased by 9% during the first six months of 2020 due to the stay-at-home order.
• The economic impact was compounded later in the year by the outbreak of hostilities in the Second Nagorno-Karabakh War against Azerbaijan, which further destabilized the Armenian economy.

• In 2018, Armenia's agricultural production included 415 thousand tons of potatoes, 199 thousand tons of vegetables, 187 thousand tons of wheat, 179 thousand tons of grapes, 138 thousand tons of tomatoes, 126 thousand tons of watermelons, 124 thousand tons of barley, 109 thousand tons of apples, 104 thousand tons of apricots, 89 thousand tons of cabbages, 54 thousand tons of sugar beet, 52 thousand tons of peaches, 50 thousand tons of cucumbers, and 39 thousand tons of onions.
• Armenia also produced smaller quantities of other agricultural products not specified in detail.
• Market sales of Armenian agricultural products include cornelian cherries, figs, pears, peaches, and apples, particularly in Yerevan.
• As of 2010, agricultural production constituted approximately 25 percent of Armenia's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• In 2006, the agricultural sector accounted for about 20 percent of Armenia's GDP.

• Armenia's agricultural output experienced a 17.9 percent decline during January–September 2010, attributed to adverse weather conditions, absence of a government stimulus package, and the ongoing effects of reduced agricultural subsidies mandated by the World Trade Organization (WTO).
• The share of agriculture in Armenia's GDP was around 17.9 percent until 2012, according to the World Bank.
• In 2013, the share increased slightly to 18.43 percent.
• A declining trend was observed from 2013 to 2017, with agriculture's contribution decreasing to approximately 14.90 percent in 2017.

• When comparing neighboring countries, Armenia's percentage of GDP from agriculture is the highest; in 2017, neighboring countries' contributions were Georgia at 6.88 percent, Azerbaijan at 5.63 percent, Turkey at 6.08 percent, and Iran at 9.05 percent.
• In 2022, the sector with the highest number of registered companies in Armenia was Services, with 1,907 companies.
• Following Services, Wholesale Trade had 510 companies, and Manufacturing had 408 companies registered in Armenia in 2022.

text:
Real estate transactions count grew by 36% in September 2019 compared to
September 2018. Also, the average market value of one square meter of housing
in apartment buildings in Yerevan in September 2019 grew by 10.8% from
September 2018.

In 2017, construction output increased by 2.2% reaching 416 billion AMD.

Armenia experienced a construction boom during the latter part of the 2000s.
According to the National Statistical Service, Armenia's booming construction
sector generated about 20 percent of Armenia's GDP during the first eight
months of 2007. According to a World Bank official, 30 percent of Armenia's
economy in 2009 came from the construction sector.

However, during the January to September 2010 period, the sector experienced a
5.2 percent year-on-year decrease, which according to the Civilitas Foundation
is an indication of the unsustainability of a sector based on an elite market,
with few products for the median or low budgets. This decrease comes despite
the fact that an important component of the government stimulus package was to
support the completion of ongoing construction projects.
openai_summarised_points: • In September 2019, the number of real estate transactions in Armenia increased by 36% compared to September 2018, indicating significant growth in the property market during that period.

• The average market value of one square meter of housing in apartment buildings in Yerevan in September 2019 rose by 10.8% compared to September 2018, reflecting a substantial increase in housing prices.
• In 2017, Armenia's construction output grew by 2.2%, reaching a total value of 416 billion AMD, demonstrating moderate expansion in the sector.
• Armenia experienced a construction boom in the late 2000s, during which the sector played a crucial role in the economy.

• According to the National Statistical Service, the construction sector contributed approximately 20% of Armenia's GDP during the first eight months of 2007, highlighting its significant economic impact at that time.
• A World Bank official stated that in 2009, about 30% of Armenia's economy was derived from the construction sector, emphasizing its importance in the national economy.
• Between January and September 2010, the construction sector in Armenia experienced a 5.2% decrease year-on-year, indicating a slowdown in activity.
• The Civilitas Foundation attributed the decline in 2010 to the sector's reliance on an elite market with limited products for median or low-income budgets, suggesting issues of sustainability.
• Despite government efforts to stimulate the sector through a package aimed at supporting ongoing construction projects, the sector still faced a downturn in the first nine months of 2010.

text:
The digital economy is a branch of the economy based on digital computing
technologies. The digital economy is sometimes referred to as the Internet
economy or the web economy. The digital economy is often intertwined with the
traditional economy, making it difficult to distinguish between them. Aimed at
the sector's development on November 15, 2021, the Silicon Mountains Summit
dedicated to introducing intelligent solutions in the economy was held in
Yerevan. The main topic of the summit was the prospect of digitalization of
the economy in Armenia. The main driving force of this sphere in Armenia is
the banks. Digital transformation is a necessity for banks and financial
institutions. At the moment, ACBA Bank is the leader․
openai_summarised_points: • The digital economy is a sector of the economy that is based on digital computing technologies.
• It is sometimes referred to as the Internet economy or the web economy.
• The digital economy is often intertwined with the traditional economy, which makes it challenging to distinguish between the two.
• On November 15, 2021, the Silicon Mountains Summit was held in Yerevan, focusing on the development of the digital economy in Armenia.
• The summit's primary theme was the prospects of digitalization of Armenia's economy and introducing intelligent solutions within it.
• The digital economy in Armenia is primarily driven by the banking sector, which acts as the main force behind its development.
• Digital transformation is considered a necessity for banks and financial institutions in Armenia to stay competitive and innovative.
• Currently, ACBA Bank is recognized as the leader in digital banking and financial services within Armenia.

industrial output (including electricity) made up about 30 percent of GDP.

text:
In 2010, retail trade turnover was largely unaltered compared to 2009. The
existing monopolies throughout the retail sector have made the sector non-
responsive to the crisis and resulted in near zero growth. The aftermath of
the crisis has started to shift the structure in the retail sector in favor of
food products.

Nowadays(2019), Armenia has improved standards of living and growing income,
which brought to the improvement of retail sector in Armenia. retail sector
has the highest employment level. While the sector improves, currently the
major sector is still in Yerevan, and not in the other cities of Armenia. The
development that happened in this sector was the opening of Dalma Garden Mall,
and later Yerevan mall, Rio mall and Rossia mall, which dramatically increased
the quality of retail in Yerevan. Currently there is a new development, as in
Gyumri there is a new mall opened called Shirak Mall. Another reason for the
development of the retail is the development that happened in the banking
industry. Today people can easily get financial assistance from the banks
right to their credit cards, without visiting the bank.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2010, retail trade turnover in Armenia remained largely unchanged compared to 2009, indicating minimal growth during that period.
• The retail sector was characterized by existing monopolies across its various segments, which rendered the sector unresponsive to economic crises and resulted in near zero growth rates.
• The aftermath of the economic crisis initiated a structural shift within Armenia’s retail sector, with a noticeable increase in the proportion of food products in retail sales.
• As of 2019, Armenia experienced improved standards of living and rising income levels, which contributed to the overall enhancement of the retail sector.
• The retail sector in Armenia has the highest employment levels among various economic sectors.
• Despite sector improvements, retail activity remains predominantly concentrated in Yerevan, with less developed retail infrastructure in other cities of Armenia.

• Significant developments in retail infrastructure include the opening of major shopping malls such as Dalma Garden Mall and subsequently Yerevan Mall, Rio Mall, and Rossia Mall, which significantly elevated the quality and scope of retail services in Yerevan.
• A recent development is the opening of Shirak Mall in Gyumri, indicating expansion of retail infrastructure beyond Yerevan.

• The growth of the retail sector has been supported by advancements in the banking industry, notably the increased ease of obtaining financial assistance, such as credit cards, directly from banks without the need for physical bank visits.

text:
Grand Hotel Yerevan, established in 1926

Tourism in Armenia has been a key sector to the Armenian economy since the
1990s when tourist numbers exceeded half a million people visiting the country
every year (mostly ethnic Armenians from the Diaspora). The Armenian Ministry
of Economy reports that most international tourists come from Russia, EU
states, the United States and Iran. Though relatively small in size, Armenia
has three UNESCO world heritage sites.

Despite internal and external problems, the number of incoming tourists has
been continually increasing. 2018 saw a record high of over 1.6 million
inbound tourists.

In 2018 receipts from international tourism amounted to $1.2 billion, nearly
twice the value for 2010. In per capita terms these stood at $413, ahead of
Turkey and Azerbaijan, but behind Georgia.

In 2019 the largest growth at 27.2% was shown by accommodation and catering
sector, which came as a result of the growth of tourist flows.
openai_summarised_points: • The Grand Hotel Yerevan was established in 1926, serving as a notable landmark in Armenia’s hospitality industry.
• Tourism has been a vital sector of Armenia’s economy since the 1990s, with annual tourist numbers exceeding half a million, primarily consisting of ethnic Armenians from the Diaspora.
• According to the Armenian Ministry of Economy, the majority of international tourists originate from Russia, European Union member states, the United States, and Iran.
• Despite its relatively small geographical size, Armenia possesses three UNESCO World Heritage sites, highlighting its cultural and historical significance.
• The number of inbound tourists to Armenia has been steadily increasing despite internal and external challenges faced by the country.
• In 2018, Armenia recorded a record high of over 1.6 million inbound tourists, marking a significant milestone in its tourism development.
• Tourism receipts in 2018 totaled approximately $1.2 billion, nearly doubling the income generated in 2010, indicating substantial growth in the sector.
• Per capita tourism expenditure in Armenia in 2018 was $413, which surpasses Turkey and Azerbaijan but remains below Georgia.
• The accommodation and catering sector experienced the largest growth in 2019, increasing by 27.2%, driven by the overall growth in tourist flows.

text:
The amount of interest paid on the public debt rose significantly (from AMD 11
billion in 2008 to AMD 46.5 billion in 2013), as did the amount of principle
repayments (from annual repayments of US$15–16 million in 2005-2008 exceeding
US$150 million in 2013). This is a significant financial load on the state
budget. Because of additional borrowings and lower concessionality of new
loans, the burden might rise in the future years.

In 2019, the Armenian government planned to obtain about $490 million in fresh
loans rising public debt to about $7.5 billion. Just over $6.9 billion of that
would be the government's debt.

After reaching nearly 60.0 per cent of GDP, the public debt to GDP ratio
decreased by approximately three percentage points in 2018 compared with a
year before and stood at 55.7 per cent at the end of 2018.

The government's public debt at the end of 2019 stood at $6.94 billion, making
50.3% of its GDP.

In March 2019 sovereign debt was $5488 million, $86.5 million (about 2%) less
than a year ago.

Other sources quote Armenia's debt at $10.8 billion in September 2018,
possibly including non-public debt too.

In 2018 debt-to-GDP ratio stood at 55.7% down from 58.7% in 2017.

Armenia revised the country's fiscal rules in 2018, setting a permissible
threshold for public debt in the amount of 40, 50 and 60% of GDP. At the same
time, it established that in case of force majeure situations such as natural
disasters, wars, the government will be allowed to exceed this threshold.

The debt rose by $863.5 million in 2016 and by another $832.5 million in 2017.
It totalled just $1.9 billion (13.5% of GDP) before the 2008 financial crisis
and the Great Recession.
openai_summarised_points: • The interest paid on Armenia's public debt increased significantly from AMD 11 billion in 2008 to AMD 46.5 billion in 2013, reflecting a substantial rise in debt servicing costs.
• The amount of principal repayments on public debt also grew markedly, from annual repayments of US$15–16 million during 2005-2008 to exceeding US$150 million in 2013.
• This escalation in debt servicing represents a significant financial burden on the Armenian state budget.
• Due to additional borrowings and the decreasing concessionality of new loans, the debt burden is projected to increase further in future years.
• In 2019, the Armenian government planned to secure approximately $490 million in new loans, which would raise the total public debt to about $7.5 billion.
• Of this total, just over $6.9 billion would constitute the government's direct debt.
• The public debt-to-GDP ratio reached nearly 60.0% but decreased by approximately three percentage points in 2018 compared to the previous year, ending at 55.7% at the end of 2018.
• The government's public debt at the end of 2019 was valued at $6.94 billion, accounting for 50.3% of Armenia's GDP.
• As of March 2019, Armenia's sovereign debt was $5,488 million, which was about $86.5 million (approximately 2%) less than the amount recorded a year earlier.
• Other sources reported Armenia's total debt at $10.8 billion in September 2018, potentially including non-public debt.
• The debt-to-GDP ratio in 2018 stood at 55.7%, down from 58.7% in 2017.

• In 2018, Armenia revised its fiscal rules to set permissible public debt thresholds at 40%, 50%, and 60% of GDP, with provisions allowing the government to exceed these thresholds in force majeure situations such as natural disasters and wars.
• The public debt increased by $863.5 million in 2016 and by an additional $832.5 million in 2017.
• Prior to the 2008 financial crisis and the Great Recession, Armenia's total public debt was approximately $1.9 billion, representing 13.5% of GDP.

text:
Central Bank of Armenia's Educational Center in Dilijan

Cash remittances from Armenians working abroad — mostly in Russia and the
United States — contribute significantly to Armenia's Gross Domestic Product
making up 14% of GDP in 2018. They help Armenia sustain double-digit economic
growth and finance its massive trade deficit.

In 2008 transfers reached record high of $2.3 billion. In 2015 they reached
10-year low at $1.6 billion. In 2018, they run at round $1.8 billion. $0.8
billion were transferred in first half of 2019. According to CBA their impact
on economy is decreasing, as GDP grows at outperforming rate.

Net private transfers decreased in 2009, but saw a continuous increase during
the first six months of 2010. Since private transfers from the Diaspora tend
to be mostly injected into consumption of imports and not in high value-added
sectors, the transfers have not resulted in sizeable increases in
productivity.

According to the Central Bank of Armenia, during the first half of 2008, cash
remittances sent back to Armenia by Armenians working abroad rose by 57.5
percent and totaled US$668.6 million, equivalent to 15 percent of the
country's first-half Gross Domestic Product. However, the latter figures only
represent cash remittances processed through Armenian commercial banks.
According to RFE/RL, comparable sums are believed to be transferred through
non-bank systems, implying that cash remittances make up approximately 30
percent of Armenia's GDP in the first half of 2008.

In 2007 cash remittances through bank transfers rose by 37 percent to a
record-high level of US$1.32 billion. According to the Central Bank of
Armenia, in 2005, cash remittances from Armenians working abroad reached a
record-high level of $1 billion, which is worth more than one fifth of the
country's 2005 GDP.
openai_summarised_points: • Cash remittances from Armenians working abroad, primarily in Russia and the United States, significantly contribute to Armenia's economy, accounting for 14% of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in 2018.
• These remittances play a crucial role in supporting Armenia's double-digit economic growth and financing its substantial trade deficit.
• In 2008, remittances reached a record high of $2.3 billion, marking the peak of financial inflows from the diaspora.
• In 2015, remittances declined to a 10-year low of $1.6 billion, reflecting fluctuations in diaspora income and economic conditions.
• By 2018, remittances slightly increased to approximately $1.8 billion.
• In the first half of 2019, $0.8 billion was transferred to Armenia via remittances.
• According to the Central Bank of Armenia (CBA), the impact of remittances on the national economy is decreasing, as Armenia's GDP grows at an outperforming rate.
• Net private transfers decreased in 2009 but experienced continuous growth during the first six months of 2010.

• Most private transfers from the Armenian diaspora are primarily used for consumption, especially imports, rather than invested in high value-added sectors, limiting their effect on productivity increases.
• During the first half of 2008, cash remittances sent home by Armenians abroad increased by 57.5%, totaling $668.6 million, which was equivalent to 15% of Armenia's first-half GDP.

• These figures represent cash remittances processed through Armenian commercial banks; however, comparable sums are believed to be transferred via non-bank systems, suggesting that total cash remittances may constitute approximately 30% of Armenia's GDP in the first half of 2008.
• In 2007, cash remittances through bank transfers rose by 37% to a record-high of $1.32 billion.
• In 2005, cash remittances from Armenians abroad reached $1 billion, which was more than one-fifth of Armenia's GDP for that year.

text:
Ameriabank headquarters in Yerevan

The central bank has set additional capital buffers in the banking sector. In
force since April 2019, the regulator set three buffers exceeding the current
capital adequacy requirement compliant with the Basel III regulation: a
capital conservation buffer, a counter-cyclical capital buffer and a systemic
risk buffer. Full implementation of the buffers over the course of the next
few years will strengthen the financial sector's resistance to economic shocks
and help increase the efficiency of macroprudential policies.

Armenian banks' lending grew by 10 percent in 2019.
openai_summarised_points: • The central bank of Armenia has established additional capital buffers within the banking sector to enhance financial stability.
• These capital buffers have been in force since April 2019.
• The regulator implemented three specific buffers that exceed the existing capital adequacy requirements aligned with Basel III standards:
• A capital conservation buffer
• A counter-cyclical capital buffer
• A systemic risk buffer
• The full implementation of these buffers is planned over the next few years, aiming to strengthen the resilience of the financial sector against economic shocks.
• The introduction of these buffers is also intended to improve the effectiveness of macroprudential policies.
• In 2019, Armenian banks experienced a 10 percent growth in lending.
• The image caption indicates that Ameriabank's headquarters is located in Yerevan.

text:
The establishment of Microfinance institutions in Armenia was dependent on
them making a complementary effort to fill the gap in the financial services
sector. Its primary goal was to deal with the rising unemployment and poverty
brought on by transitory shock. In this context, self-employment in the
country emerged as one of the best options to unemployment. Commercial banking
institutions in Armenia overlooked micro-business enterprises that lacked
credit histories and sufficient funding. Microfinance has been proposed as an
adaptable instrument to assist people in transition economies take advantage
of new opportunities.
openai_summarised_points: • The establishment of microfinance institutions in Armenia was driven by the need to complement existing financial services and address gaps within the sector.
• The primary goal of these institutions was to combat rising unemployment and poverty caused by transitory economic shocks.
• In the Armenian context, self-employment emerged as one of the most effective strategies to mitigate unemployment.
• Commercial banking institutions in Armenia tended to overlook micro-business enterprises that lacked established credit histories and sufficient funding.
• Microfinance was proposed as a flexible and adaptable instrument to support individuals in transition economies, enabling them to capitalize on new economic opportunities.

text:
In August 2019 Moody's Investors Service upgraded Armenia to Ba3 rating with
stable outlook.

According to the National Statistical Service, Armenia's government debt stood
at AMD 3.1 trillion (about $6,4 billion, including $5,1 billion of external
debt) as of November 30, 2017. Armenia's debt-to-GDP ratio will drop by 1% in
2018 according to finance minister.

In Armenia's external debt ($5.5 billion as of January 1, 2018), the arrears
for multi-country credit programs dominate – 66.2% or $3.6 billion, followed
by debt on bilateral loan programs - 17.5% or $958.9 million and investments
of non-residents in Armenian Eurobonds – 15,4% or $844.9 million.

For the whole Armenian economy and international commerce, 2020 was a year of
decline. In a variety of areas Armenian commodities are being exported and
imported at a lower rate. According to the Armenian Statistical Committee,
Armenia exported goods worth $2.544 billion in 2020, a fall of 3.9 percent
from 2019. Armenia imported items worth 4.559 billion dollars in 2020, down
17.7% from the previous year.The volume of Armenia's international trade has
varied throughout the previous 10 years.
openai_summarised_points: • In August 2019, Moody's Investors Service upgraded Armenia's credit rating to Ba3 with a stable outlook, indicating a moderate investment risk and stable economic prospects.
• According to the National Statistical Service, Armenia's government debt was AMD 3.1 trillion as of November 30, 2017, which is approximately $6.4 billion, including $5.1 billion of external debt.
• Armenia's debt-to-GDP ratio was projected to decrease by 1% in 2018, as stated by the Armenian finance minister, reflecting efforts to improve fiscal stability.
• As of January 1, 2018, Armenia's external debt totaled $5.5 billion, with the majority comprising arrears for multi-country credit programs, accounting for 66.2% or $3.6 billion.
• Bilateral loan program debts constituted 17.5% or $958.9 million of Armenia's external debt, while investments by non-residents in Armenian Eurobonds made up 15.4% or $844.9 million.
• The year 2020 marked a decline for Armenia's economy and international commerce, characterized by reduced export and import activities across various sectors.
• According to the Armenian Statistical Committee, Armenia exported goods worth $2.544 billion in 2020, representing a 3.9% decrease compared to 2019.
• In 2020, Armenia imported goods valued at $4.559 billion, which is a 17.7% reduction from the previous year.
• Over the past decade, Armenia's international trade volume has experienced fluctuations, reflecting varying economic conditions and external factors impacting trade activities.

text:
From January 1, 2020, Armenia will switch to a flat income taxation system,
which, regardless of the amount will tax wages at 23%. Moreover, until 2023
the taxation rate will gradually decrease from 23% to 20%.
openai_summarised_points: • Starting from January 1, 2020, Armenia implemented a transition to a flat income taxation system.
• Under this new system, all wages are taxed at a uniform rate of 23%, regardless of income level.
• The taxation rate is scheduled to gradually decrease from 23% to 20% by the year 2023.
• This gradual reduction in the income tax rate is part of Armenia’s fiscal policy adjustments over the specified period.

text:
The reform adopted in June 2019 aims to boost medium-term economic activity
and to increase tax compliance. Among other measures, the corporate income tax
was reduced by two percentage points to 18.0 per cent and the tax on dividends
for non-resident organisations halved to 5.0 per cent.
openai_summarised_points: • The reform adopted in June 2019 was designed to stimulate medium-term economic activity in Armenia.
• One of the primary objectives of the reform was to enhance tax compliance among taxpayers.
• As part of the reform measures, the corporate income tax rate was reduced by two percentage points, lowering it from its previous rate to 18.0 percent.
• The tax on dividends paid to non-resident organizations was halved, decreasing from its previous rate to 5.0 percent.

text:
From January 1, 2020, the republic will abandon two alternative tax systems -
self-employed and family entrepreneurship. They will be replaced by micro-
entrepreneurship with a non-taxable threshold of up to 24 million drams.
Business entities that carry out specialized activities, in particular,
accounting, advocacy, and consulting will not be considered as micro-business
entities. Micro business will be exempted from all types of taxes other than
income tax, which will be 5 thousand drams per employee.
openai_summarised_points: • Starting from January 1, 2020, Armenia will abolish two alternative tax systems: the self-employed system and the family entrepreneurship system.
• These abolished systems will be replaced by a new micro-entrepreneurship regime.
• The micro-entrepreneurship system will have a non-taxable income threshold of up to 24 million drams.
• Business entities engaged in specialized activities such as accounting, advocacy, and consulting will not be classified as micro-business entities under this new regime.
• Micro-business entities will be exempt from all types of taxes except for income tax.
• The income tax for micro-business entities will be set at 5 thousand drams per employee.

text:
Over half of the tax revenues in January–August 2008 were generated from
value-added taxes (VAT) of 20%. By comparison, corporate profit tax generated
less than 16 percent of the revenues. This suggests that tax collection in
Armenia is improving at the expense of ordinary citizens, rather than wealthy
citizens (who have been the main beneficiaries of Armenia's double-digit
economic growth in recent years).

VAT (Value Added Tax): In Armenia, VAT-paying individuals subtract the VAT
paid on their inputs from the VAT levied on their sales and account to the tax
authorities for the difference. The standard rate of VAT on domestic sales of
goods and services, as well as imports importation, is 20%. Exports of
products and services are not taxed.
openai_summarised_points: • In the period of January–August 2008, over 50% of Armenia's tax revenues were derived from value-added taxes (VAT) at a rate of 20%.
• During the same period, corporate profit tax contributed less than 16% of the total tax revenues, indicating a relatively smaller share compared to VAT.

• The data suggests that Armenia's tax collection efforts are primarily benefiting ordinary citizens rather than the wealthy, who have historically been the main beneficiaries of the country's recent double-digit economic growth.

• In Armenia, VAT-paying individuals calculate their tax obligations by subtracting the VAT paid on their inputs from the VAT charged on their sales, and then remit the difference to the tax authorities.
• The standard VAT rate applied to domestic sales of goods and services, as well as imports, is 20%.
• Exports of products and services in Armenia are exempt from VAT, meaning they are not taxed.
